channel.title: Rossana & Olivier in ...
channel.description: Recent content on Rossana & Olivier in ...
channel.copyright: 2018 Rossana & Olivier in ... powered by Hugo and hosted on Github.

item.title: Porongurup, it's us again
item.description: Going back to Nic, Scottie and Emerson's house is a bit like going home after a long absence.

item.title: On the road again
item.description: Let's go back on track, and specifically the one leading to .

item.title: Ciao Gunns Plains
item.description: The two months initially planned to visit Tasmania stretch like chewing gum (9 months at last count), which is a must for our fitness.

item.title: Gunns Plains bis
item.description: "Hey guys, the weather is going to be sunny for a few days.

item.title: Gunns Plains
item.description: We arrive at Penny and Steve's cottage on a gloomy rainy day .

item.title: Bye bye Ashbolt farm
item.description: The idea was to make a nice video to show how olives are turned into oil .

item.title: 24h at Ashbolt Farm
item.description: "No milk today my love is gone away", "No one knows what it's like, to be the bad man" are the first words we hear this morning.

item.title: Ashbolt Farm
item.description: The cabin of Lorinna Valley was a bit narrow for all these people, so we are looking for other good souls to accommodate us.

item.title: Lorinna Valley
item.description: If you follow the (doomsday) prepper philosophy (you know, the ones who plan and train to survive the end of the civilized world), in the event of a pandemic, you must isolate in a place easy to defend and rich in renewable resources (water and food).

item.title: With Liz and Do
item.description: For Katy to benefit from the Mentos freely (without two uptight people all the time over her shoulder), we plan two weeks of volunteering north of Melbourne.

item.title: Eyre Peninsula
item.description: What makes a jetty so important for Australians? Historically, any self-respecting coastal village must, sooner or later, ask the government to build a jetty.

item.title: Adelaide and Flinders Range
item.description: "Knock, knock, knock. Anyone there?" We're in one of Adelaide's main streets, on the first floor of the youth hostel.

item.title: The Nullarbor
item.description: Before reaching the plains of the Nullarbor, the authentic treeless region (Nullarbor meaning "no tree" in Latin), we first have to leave Western Australia.

item.title: Esperance
item.description: Here we go for a few days of volunteering with Georgina, Jürg and their teenager Gian-Luca.

item.title: Fitzgerald River National Park
item.description: Step by step by gathering information from our discussions and cross-checking, we begin to better understand the Australian school system.

item.title: Porongurup Pure tris
item.description: Time goes on peacefully, at the pace of the animals .

item.title: Porongurup Pure bis
item.description: Rain, wind, a cloudy sky, it's cold (according to Australian standards), no doubt, we're back in the Porongurup!

item.title: The wild flower way
item.description: Another few hundred kilometers of gravel roads before our wheels reach the tarmac of the highway.

item.title: Carey Downs bis
item.description: What changed at Carey Downs in a month? Harry, Alys and family spend some time in August wandering around Western Australia.

item.title: Pilbara and Kimberley (2/2)
item.description: Houston, we have problem. We are losing pressure : the Mentos, our coach, drove on a screw .

item.title: Pilbara and Kimberley (1/2)
item.description: Red is the color that represents this part of the world.

item.title: Carey Downs Station
item.description: We wanted to get off the beaten track. A gigantic cattle farm a hundred kilometres of dirt road off Gascoyne Junction (20 houses, a school, a post office, a gas station and a campsite) sounds pretty good!

item.title: Up the west coast
item.description: Just out of the plane, Sébastien, the very special package and also Olivier's brother, has only one goal: go swimming in the Indian Ocean.

item.title: Porongurup Pure
item.description: Life has been so easy for the last two months. A farm seems the right choice not to get rusty : there is always something to do!

item.title: Southwest National Parks
item.description: When you say Australia, you think beach, desert and big red rock.

item.title: Boranup
item.description: The first interview with our new host, Malcom, takes place at the Boranup Campground.

item.title: Perth to Augusta
item.description: The basic development of the Mentos is finished. We put the last unused wood plates behind the bed for a version 2.

item.title: The mentos
item.description: Choosing your ride is a crucial step for backpacker. Without hesitation, we make up our mind for a campervan.

item.title: Perth, at David's
item.description: Spring was slowly coming up in Belgium but we had other plans on the other side of the world.

item.title: British Isles
item.description: Rokiwi has a new look and is back in service .

item.title: Thaïlande - Partie 2
item.description: Pirom makes sure we got a place where to go before letting us wander again.

item.title: Thailand - Part 1
item.description: After 11 months spent in the southern hemisphere, it wouldn't be wise to go back home too quickly: that's why we're having a break in the tropics, in the North East of Thailand (Isan region).

item.title: Dagg Family
item.description: Hard to face the reality but this is already our last stop on kiwi land : Auckland, the biggest city and the hub that nearly every tourist goes through.

item.title: Northland Ⅱ
item.description: Kiwi aren't particularly rebellious and popeyed when French farmers go along the Champs-Élysées with their tractor to protest.

item.title: Mimiwhangata Coastal Park
item.description: What's happening? Wanting to try something else? After nine months of wwoofing, we switch from couch surfing last week to volunteering now!

item.title: Northland : Part 1
item.description: Because of New Zealand geography, it's compulsory to go through Auckland if you want to go North.

item.title: Linden and Richard
item.description: Pschkr ... " Richard to Linden! I can see one more, two meters below where you are .

item.title: Tongariro and Co.
item.description: After a short week of resettlement to New Zealand, the call to outback adventure is hard to resist.

item.title: Samoa
item.description: Or why the hell is this article published so late...

item.title: Hangi
item.description: Tools and ingredients paper to start the fire firewood shovel big volcanic rocks or heavy iron pieces metal basket jute cloths cabbage or leek leaves kumara pumpkin potatoes stuffed chicken stuffed lamb Recipe Dig a hole in the ground slightly bigger than the metal basket.

item.title: Tairawhiti
item.description: Networking is as efficient at finding a job as at entering an out of the beaten track wwoofing.

item.title: Beehive garden
item.description: Exit the assembly-line work in a vineyard, we re-tool in "artistic horticulture".

item.title: Across the Cook Strait
item.description: You, northern hemisphere inhabitant, might be dreaming of air conditioning or a swimming pool while we are begging for some warmth so we decide to head north.

item.title: Waipara Valley
item.description: Monday morning, 8am, like everybody, we're going to work... What's special about us ?

item.title: Sue and Nev. Again!
item.description: Our next destination is Greta Valley again, at Sue and Nev's, our first wwoofing where everything began.

item.title: Back to the origin
item.description: Sue and Nev (our first wwoofing) were so friendly. Why not going back :) ?

item.title: Landfall Estate
item.description: What do you think of English producing French wine in New Zealand?

item.title: Nothern South
item.description: Autumn is getting to us : dark at 6:30pm, wet weather or even real showers.

item.title: TreeDimensions
item.description: New wwoofing means new diet and new boss :). Dieter introduced us to biodynamics, vegetarianism and german organisation (Bavarian to be accurate).

item.title: From South to North
item.description: Already three months we have been having a great time in NZ.

item.title: Sherry and Jeff
item.description: On the way to our next woofing, we follow the South Coast from Fiordland to Invercargill.

item.title: Le Fjordland
item.description: Like everybody we wanted to visit Fiordland and its famous Milford sound.

item.title: Andrew and Deborah
item.description: Is it possible to be a farmer and an IT specialist at the same time?

item.title: The Catlins
item.description: After 6 long days spent weeding Shaun's vegetables, we're on the road again to the Catlins.

item.title: A Week Off
item.description: Unfortunately we can't stay forever at Sue 'n Nev's, the rest of New Zealand is waiting for us.

item.title: Sue 'n Nev
item.description: First kiwi stop: Sue and Nev's woofing. Such a lovely place!
